reviewText: Liz Curtis Higgs is an author whose insights and humor make Bible study a true delight.  In "Really Bad Girls of the Bible," Higgs examines the lives of eight less-than-stellar women from God's Holy Word.  The Medium of Endor, Jael, the Adulterous Woman in John 8, Athaliah, Bathsheba, Herodias, the Widow Tamar, and the sick woman in Mark 5 are the women who are examined.  Higgs never minces words, and her candid insights force us all to contemplate our own lives.  Higgs confesses her own wrongdoings; making reading this book feel like a Bible study between friends.  My favorite chapters are:1. "Lethal Weapon: Jael: A "tent peg wielding warrior princess" whose grisly murder of a bloodthirsty military leader of Israel's enemies, the Canaanites, has echoed throughout history.  God uses shocking actions and anyone whom He desires to accomplish His plans.2. "Athaliah": Like mother, like daughter! The power-hungry queen, daughter of Ahab and Jezebel, will stop at nothing to seize control of the tribe of Judah, even if this fact means the slaughter of her own grandchildren.3. "Just Desserts: Herodias": A ruthless woman bent upon revenge shamelessly manipulates her own little girl to accomplish her goals.4. "Bathsheba": A lustful king whose sins have lasting consequences, but whose contrition and confession to a loving God illustrate grace for all mankind: "If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just and will forgive us our sins" (1 John 1).5. "The Adultrous": This chapter brought me to tears.  "Let him who is without sin among you be the first to throw a stone at her" (John 8).  Thank you, Holy Savior, for your boundless love!6. "The Sick Woman": Since sickness was considered a sin during the time of Jesus, the poor woman in Mark 5 was shunned by an unforgiving society.  However, her belief and simple act of faith in Jesus's healing powers stands as an unforgettable testimony.  All of us can come to the flowing fountain of Jesus's grace: to the healing flow that issues from His life-giving blood: (For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus" (Romans 6-18-19).  Other outstanding verses are: (John 3-16, Acts 2-38, Acts Chapter 8, and Acts Chapter 16).The beginning of each chapter includes a fictional contemporary story that emphasizes the still-applicable truths of these biblical accounts.  My favorite fictional account is in the chapter on the Adultrous Woman.  This book would be excellent for use in a Sunday School class.Please read this book to learn and be encouraged.  We're all "bad girls and boys," but we can be free! Happy reading, and God bless you all.

reviewText: This book is just as good, and maybe even better, than its predecessor, "Bad Girls of the Bible."  In "Really Bad Girls", Liz Curtis Higgs follows the same format and conveys the same message as the first.  She brings the reader's attention to often-overlooked women in the Bible, such as Jael, Athalia, and the Medium of En-Dor (no, not the planet the Ewoks live on!).  She brings these "bad girls" to life and makes their stories relevent to today's women through modern-retelling of the stories.  At the end of each study, she tells us what we can learn from them and that, most of all, God will forgive us and love us no matter what.Her "Bad Girls" books have really caught on like wildfire in the Christian community, and no doubt have captured the hearts of many non-Christians as well.  Her books are different and edgy, which is just what the Christian literary community needs.  As a reformed "bad girl" herself, Liz speaks as somebody who has been through it all and lived to tell about it.  She welcomes every woman, no matter what her background, with open arms and an open heart.  Even if you don't really consider yourself a "Christian", you will be completely won over by her books and message.  Actually, I believe she wrote her books as much for those outside the Christian community as those within it.I was so touched by her books that I emailed Liz herself telling her what a difference they made in my life.  She sent an encouraging, heart-felt message back, which totally made my day!  How many authors out there will do that?  Liz is definitely one-of-a-kind!
summary: A witty and insightful look at the Bible's "bad girls"
